{{update|date=July 2018}} {{Use South African English|date=May 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} [[File:Map-of-HIV-Prevalance-in-Africa.png|thumb|300px|right|Estimated HIV prevalence among adults aged 15-49 by country in 2007]] HIV/AIDS is the most serious health concern in South Africa. The country has the fourth-highest adult HIV prevalence rate in the world, according to the 2016 United Nations statistics.<ref name="databank.worldbank.org">{{Cite web|url=http://databank.worldbank.org/data/reports.aspx?source=2&series=SH.DYN.AIDS.ZS&country=ZAF#|title=World Development Indicators {{!}} DataBank|website=databank.worldbank.org|access-date=2018-03-18}}</ref>
According to a UNAids dataset sourced from the World Bank, in 2016 the HIV prevalence rate for adults aged 15 to 49 was 27% in Swaziland, 25% in Lesotho, 25% in Botswana and 19% in South Africa.<ref name="databank.worldbank.org"/>
== Understanding HIV prevalence ==
[[List of countries by HIV/AIDS adult prevalence rate|HIV prevalence]] does not indicate that a country has an AIDS crisis, as HIV and AIDS are separate conditions. HIV prevalence, instead, indicates that people remain alive, despite the infection. South Africa has the largest HIV treatment programme in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://africacheck.org/reports/yes-south-africa-has-the-worlds-largest-antiretroviral-therapy-programme/|title=Yes, South Africa has the world’s largest antiretroviral therapy programme|last=Wilkinson|first=Kate|date=12 February 2018|website=Africa Check|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=18 March 2018}}</ref> With the correct medication, HIV is a manageable chronic condition, like diabetes or hypertension. A population with a larger proportion of diabetics, means more people are receiving treatment for the condition. Hence, a population with a larger proportion of HIV-positive people, means more people are receiving [[Management of HIV/AIDS|anti-retroviral treatment]].
[[World Bank]] [[Open data|Open Data]] explains the data it publishes on HIV prevalence as follows:
{{quote |HIV prevalence rates reflect the rate of HIV infection in each country's population. Low national prevalence rates can be misleading, however. They often disguise epidemics that are initially concentrated in certain localities or population groups and threaten to spill over into the wider population. In many developing countries most new infections occur in young adults, with young women especially vulnerable.
Data on HIV are from the Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAids). Changes in procedures and assumptions for estimating the data and better coordination with countries have resulted in improved estimates of HIV and AIDS. The models, which are routinely updated, track the course of HIV epidemics and their impact, making full use of information in HIV prevalence trends from surveillance data as well as survey data. The models take into account reduced infectivity among people receiving antiretroviral therapy (which is having a larger impact on HIV prevalence and allowing HIV-positive people to live longer) and allow for changes in urbanization over time in generalized epidemics. The estimates include plausibility bounds, which reflect the certainty associated with each of the estimates.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://databank.worldbank.org/data/reports.aspx?source=2&series=SH.DYN.AIDS.ZS&country=# |title=Prevalence of HIV, total (ages 14-49)|last=World Bank|first=Open Data|date=22 March 2018|website=World Bank Open Data|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=18 March 2018}}</ref> }}
South Africa's HIV treatment programme was launched in earnest in 2005.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://southafrica-info.com/infographics/infographic-hiv-aids-south-africa-1990-2016/|title=Infographic: HIV and Aids in South Africa 1990 to 2016 - South Africa Gateway|date=2018-02-20|work=South Africa Gateway|access-date=2018-03-18|language=en-GB}}</ref> The trend in South Africa's HIV and AIDS statistics has changed significantly in the years since then.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://southafrica-info.com/infographics/infographic-hiv-aids-south-africa-1990-2016/|title=Infographic: HIV and Aids in South Africa 1990 to 2016 - South Africa Gateway|date=2018-02-20|work=South Africa Gateway|access-date=2018-03-20|language=en-GB}}</ref>
== Latest data on HIV prevalence in South Africa == The [[World Bank]] and [[United Nations]] source their data on HIV prevalence from [[Statistics South Africa]].
According to [[Statistics South Africa]]'s<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.statssa.gov.za/|title=Statistics South Africa {{!}} The South Africa I Know, The Home I Understand|last=Africa|first=Statistics South|website=www.statssa.gov.za|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-20}}</ref> mid-year population estimates for 2017,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.statssa.gov.za/?page_id=1854&PPN=P0302|title=Mid-Year Population Estimates 2017 {{!}} Statistics South Africa|last=Staitistics South Africa|first=|date=|website=www.statssa.gov.za|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-20}}</ref> the total HIV prevalence rate for the country is 12.6%. The HIV prevalence rate for all adults aged 15 to 49 is 17.9%, for women aged 15 to 49 is 21.2%, and for youth aged 15 to 24 is 4.6%.<ref name=":0" />
Statistics South Africa estimates the number of deaths attributable to AIDS in 2017 as 126,755 or 25.03% of all South African deaths.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://southafrica-info.com/infographics/infographic-hiv-aids-south-africa-1990-2016/|title=Infographic: HIV and Aids in South Africa 1990 to 2016 - South Africa Gateway|date=2018-02-20|work=South Africa Gateway|access-date=2018-03-20|language=en-GB}}</ref>
== Other statistics ==
=== By race === {{Main|HIV/AIDS in South African townships}} A 2008 study revealed that HIV/AIDS infection in South Africa was distinctly divided along racial lines: 13.6% of [[Black people|Black Africans]] in South Africa are HIV-positive, whereas only 0.3% of [[Whites]] living in South Africa have the disease.<ref name="ten">{{cite web|url=http://www.avert.org/south-africa-hiv-aids-statistics.htm|title=HIV and AIDS in South Africa|date=21 July 2015|website=Avert.org|accessdate=26 August 2017}}</ref> False traditional beliefs about HIV/AIDS, which contribute to the spread of the disease, persist in townships due to the lack of education and awareness programmes in these regions. [[Sexual violence in South Africa|Sexual violence]] and local attitudes toward HIV/AIDS have also amplified the epidemic.
=== By gender=== HIV/AIDS is more prevalent among females, especially those under the age of 40. Women made up roughly 4 in every 5 people with HIV/AIDS aged 20–24, and 2 out of 3 of those aged 25–29. Although prevalence is higher among women in general, only 1 in every 6 HIV/AIDS infected people with multiple sex partners are women.<ref name="ten" />
Young boys and girls in South Africa are both highly affected by intimate partner violence and HIV/AIDS. Research has found links between the two, as well as a relationship with drug use. It was found that problem drinking and marijuana use are mediating variables in the relationship between men who experienced [[childhood sexual abuse]] and who engage in HIV sexual risk behaviors.<ref>Icard LD, Jemmott, John B., I., II, Teitelman A, O’Leary A, Heeren GA. Mediation effects of problem drinking and marijuana use on HIV sexual risk behaviors among childhood sexually abused South African heterosexual men. Child Abuse & Neglect, 2014; 38(2): 234-242</ref>
In adult and adolescent women, low relationship power and victimization by intimate partner violence were found to be linked to HIV risk. This lower relationship power affects interpersonal dynamics that increase sexual risk due to condom nonuse and the likelihood of a girl with low relationship power having more sexual partners. However, both boys and girls with lower relationship power were found to be more likely to have multiple partners. Regardless of gender, youths with lower power are more vulnerable to be pressured or coerced into transactional sex.<ref>Teitelman AM, Jemmott III, JB, Bellamy SL, Icard, LD, O’Leary A, Heeren GA, Ngwane Z. Ratcliffe SJ. Partner violence, power and gender differences in South African adolescents’ HIV/STI behaviors. Health Psychology. 2016; 35(7): 751–760. doi: 10.1037/hea0000351</ref>
=== By pregnant women === HIV prevalence among pregnant women is highest in the populous [[KwaZulu-Natal]] province (37%), and lowest in the Western Cape (13%), Northern Cape (16%) and Limpopo (18%) provinces. In the five other provinces (Eastern Cape, Free State, Gauteng, Mpumalanga and North West) at least 26% of women attending [[Prenatal care|antenatal clinics]] in 2006 tested HIV-positive.
The latest HIV data collected at antenatal clinics suggest that HIV infection levels might be levelling off, with HIV prevalence in pregnant women at 30% in 2007, 29% in 2006, and 28% in 2005. The decrease in the percentage of young pregnant women (15–24 years) found to be infected with HIV can be extrapolated to suggest a possible decline in the annual number of new infections.<ref>{{cite web|title=The national hiv and syphilis prevalence survey south africa 2007 |publisher=The South African Department of Health |url=http://www.health-e.org.za/resources/reports.php |accessdate=22 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081010193647/http://www.health-e.org.za/resources/reports.php |archivedate=10 October 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref>
=== By age === Between 2005 and 2008, the number of older teenagers with HIV/AIDS has nearly halved.<ref name="5890Setswe">{{cite web|url=http://www.hsrc.ac.za/research/output/outputDocuments/5890_Setswe_HIVandAIDSepidemicinSA.pdf|title=The HIV and AIDS epidemic in South Africa: Where are we?|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726214206/http://www.hsrc.ac.za/research/output/outputDocuments/5890_Setswe_HIVandAIDSepidemicinSA.pdf|archivedate=26 July 2011|deadurl=yes|accessdate=15 May 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Between 2002 and 2008, prevalence among South Africans over 20 years old have increased whereas the figure for those under 20 years old have dropped somewhat over the same period.<ref name=5890Setswe/>
Condom use is highest among the youth and lowest among older people. More than 80% of men and more than 70% of women under 25 years old use condoms, and slightly more than half of men and women aged 25–49 claim to use condoms.<ref name=5890Setswe/>
More than 30% of young adults and more than 80% of older adults are aware of the dangers posed by HIV/AIDS. Knowledge about HIV/AIDS is lowest among people older than 50 years—less than two thirds know exactly what HIV/AIDS is.<ref name=5890Setswe/>
=== By province === {{Further|HIV/AIDS in South African townships}} In 2008, more than half (55%) of all South Africans infected with HIV resided in the KwaZulu-Natal and Gauteng provinces.<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite web| title = Sub-Saharan Africa AIDS epidemic update. Regional Summary| publisher = [[UNAIDS]]| url = http://data.unaids.org/pub/Report/2008/jc1526_epibriefs_ssafrica_en.pdf| accessdate = 22 October 2008| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081029182033/http://data.unaids.org/pub/Report/2008/jc1526_epibriefs_ssafrica_en.pdf| archivedate = 29 October 2008| df = dmy-all}}</ref>
Between 2005 and 2008, the total number of people infected with HIV/AIDS has increased in all of South Africa's provinces except KwaZulu-Natal and Gauteng. Nevertheless, KwaZulu-Natal still has the highest infection rate at 15.5% In the province with the lowest infection rate, the Western Cape, the total number of people with HIV/AIDS doubled between 2005 and 2008.<ref name=5890Setswe/>
Condom use has increased twofold in all provinces between 2002 and 2008. The two provinces where condoms were least used in 2002 were also the provinces where condoms are least used in 2008, namely the Northern Cape and the Western Cape.<ref name=5890Setswe/>
HIV/AIDS prevalence among sexually active South Africans by province are:
* KwaZulu-Natal: 25.8%. * Mpumalanga: 23.1% * Free State: 18.5% * North West: 17.7% * Gauteng: 15.2% * Eastern Cape: 15.2% * Limpopo: 13.7% * Northern Cape: 9.2% * Western Cape: 5.3%
== Awareness campaigns == The four main HIV/AIDS awareness campaigns in South Africa are [[Khomanani]] (funded by the government), [[loveLife South Africa|LoveLife]] (primarily privately funded), [[Soul City (HIV/AIDS campaign)|Soul City]] (a television drama for adults) and [[Soul Buddyz]] (a television series for teenagers).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hsrc.ac.za/Document-3239.phtml |title=slide 33 |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726213925/http://www.hsrc.ac.za/Document-3239.phtml |archivedate=26 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Soul City and Soul Buddyz are the most successful campaigns although both campaigns experienced a slight loss of effectiveness between 2005 and 2008. Khomanani is the least successful campaign, although its effectiveness has increased by more than 50% between 2005 and 2008.
The dubious quality of condoms which are distributed is a setback to these efforts. In 2007, the government recalled more than 20 million locally manufactured condoms which were defective. Some of the contraceptive devices given away at the ANC's centenary celebrations in 2012 failed a water test conducted by the [[Treatment Action Campaign]].<ref>{{cite news| newspaper = The Guardian| url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jan/31/south-africa-recalls-anc-condoms| date = 31 January 2012| title = South Africa recalls 1m ANC condoms: Scores of people given free condoms at the party's centenary celebrations have complained that they are faulty}}</ref>
== Co-infection with tuberculosis == In 2007, it was estimated that one third of HIV infected people will develop TB ([[tuberculosis]]) in their lifetimes. In 2006, 40% of TB patients were tested for HIV. It has been the government policy since 2002 to cross-check all new cases of TB for HIV infection.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.doh.gov.za/docs/reports/2008/progress/part2.pdf |title=South Africa – Country Progress Report |website=Doh.gov.za |format=PDF |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110620024839/http://doh.gov.za/docs/reports/2008/progress/part2.pdf |archivedate=20 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Although STI prevention is part of the government's HIV/AIDS programmes, as is that of most countries, in South Africa HIV/AIDS prevention is done in conjunction with TB prevention. Most patients who die from HIV-related causes die from TB or similar illnesses. In fact the Health Department's programme of prevention is called the "National HIV and AIDS and TB Programme".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.doh.gov.za/aids/docs/aids_unit.html |title=National HIV/AIDS and TB Unit, National Department of Health, Pretoria |publisher=Doh.gov.za |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110619141340/http://doh.gov.za/aids/docs/aids_unit.html |archivedate=19 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In line with United Nations requirements, South Africa has also drawn up an "HIV & AIDS and STI Strategic Plan".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.info.gov.za/otherdocs/2007/aidsplan2007/background.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-06-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907071435/http://www.info.gov.za/otherdocs/2007/aidsplan2007/background.pdf |archivedate=7 September 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== History == In 1983, AIDS was diagnosed for the first time in two patients in South Africa.<ref name=autogenerated1>Ras GJ, Simson IW, Anderson R, Prozesky OW, Hamersma T. Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome. A report of 2 South African cases. S Afr Med J 1983 Jul 23; 64(4): 140–2.</ref> The first recorded AIDS-related death occurred in the same year.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
===1990=== In 1990, the first national antenatal survey to test for HIV found that 0.8% of pregnant women were HIV-positive. It was estimated that there were between 74,000 and 6,500,135 people in South Africa living with HIV.
===1993=== In 1993, the HIV prevalence rate among pregnant women was 4.3%. By 1993, the National Health Department reported that the number of recorded HIV infections had increased by 60% in the previous two years and the number was expected to double in 1993.
===1995=== In August 1995, the [[Department of Health (South Africa)|Department of Health]] awarded a R14.27-million contract to produce a sequel to the musical, ''[[Sarafina! (musical)|Sarafina!]]'', about AIDS, in order to reach young people.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.healthlink.org.za/pphc/Phila/sarafina.htm |title=The Sarafina II Controversy |publisher=Healthlink.org.za |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007163642/http://www.healthlink.org.za/pphc/Phila/sarafina.htm |archivedate=7 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The project was dogged by controversy, and was finally shelved in 1996.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.doh.gov.za/docs/pr/1996/pr0605.html |title=Zuma'S Response To Sarafina Ii |publisher=Doh.gov.za |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110619184301/http://doh.gov.za/docs/pr/1996/pr0605.html |archivedate=19 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
From 6 to 10 March 1995, the 7th International Conference for People Living with HIV and AIDS was held in [[Cape Town]], South Africa.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aids.org/atn/a-215-07.html |title=International Conference for People Living with HIV and AIDS, Cape Town, South Africa, March 6–10; Pre- Conference for Wo |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719170032/http://www.aids.org/atn/a-215-07.html |archivedate=19 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The conference was opened by then-Deputy President [[Thabo Mbeki]].<ref>[http://70.84.171.10/~etools/newsbrief/1995/news0304] {{dead link|date=August 2017}}</ref>
===1996=== In January 1996, it was decided that South Africa's national soccer team, [[Bafana Bafana]], would contribute to the AIDS Awareness Campaign by wearing red ribbons to all their public appearances during the [[Africa Cup of Nations|Africa Nations Cup]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.info.gov.za/speeches/1996/96j15_0w825.htm |title=Bafana Endorses Aids Awareness Campaign |publisher=Info.gov.za |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604103322/http://www.info.gov.za/speeches/1996/96j15_0w825.htm |archivedate=4 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 5 July 1996,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aegis.org/news/bar/1996/BR960502.html |title=AEGiS-BAR: Vancouver or bust |publisher=Aegis.org |date=13 May 1996 |accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref> South Africa's Health Minister, [[Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma]], spoke at the 11th [[International Conference on AIDS]] in [[Vancouver]]. She said:
: ''Most people infected with HIV live in Africa, where therapies involving combinations of expensive [anti-retroviral] drugs are out of the question.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukzn.ac.za/heard/research/ResearchReports/2005/Environment+Report/APPENDIXES.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=19 January 2007|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=26 August 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070119180300/http://www.ukzn.ac.za/heard/research/ResearchReports/2005/Environment%20Report/APPENDIXES.pdf|archivedate=19 January 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===1997=== In February 1997, South African government's Health Department defended its support for the controversial AIDS drug [[Virodene]] by stating that "the 'cocktails' that are available [for the treatment of HIV/AIDS] are way beyond the means of most patients [even from developed countries]".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.info.gov.za/speeches/1997/02070x44397.htm |title=Dr. N C Zuma On Virodene Controversy |publisher=Info.gov.za |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604103407/http://www.info.gov.za/speeches/1997/02070x44397.htm |archivedate=4 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Parliament had previously launched an investigation into the procedural soundness of the clinical trials for the drug.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.info.gov.za/speeches/1997/03030w67697.htm |title=Response To Virodene Investigation |publisher=Info.gov.za |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604103418/http://www.info.gov.za/speeches/1997/03030w67697.htm |archivedate=4 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
=== 1999 === In 1999, the South African HIV prevention campaign [[loveLife South Africa|LoveLife]] was founded.
=== 2000 === In 2000, the Department of Health outlined a five-year plan to combat AIDS, HIV and STIs. A National AIDS Council (SANAC) was set up to oversee these developments.
===2001=== The South African government successfully defended against a legal action brought by [[Transnational compaines|transnational]] [[pharmaceutical companies]] in April 2001 of a law that would allow cheaper locally produced medicines, including anti-retrovirals, although the government's roll-out of anti-retrovirals remained generally slow.
In 2001, [[Right to Care]], an NGO dedicated to the prevention and treatment of HIV and associated diseases, was founded. Using [[USAID]]'s [[PEPFAR]] funding, the organisation expanded rapidly and after ten years (2011) had over 125,000 HIV-positive patients in clinical care.
===2002=== In 2002, South Africa's [[Constitutional Court of South Africa|Constitutional Court]] ordered the government to remove restrictions on the drug [[nevirapine]] and make it available to pregnant women in all state hospitals and clinics to help [[HIV and pregnancy#Prevention of mother-to-child transmission|prevent mother-to-child transmission of HIV]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://southafrica-info.com/people/hiv-aids-south-africa/|title=HIV and Aids in South Africa - South Africa Gateway|date=2018-02-12|work=South Africa Gateway|access-date=2018-02-14|language=en-GB}}</ref> following a court challenge by [[Treatment Action Campaign]] and others.
== Demographics == According to the National HIV and Syphilis Antenatal Sero-prevalence Survey of 2005<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.doh.gov.za/docs/reports/2005/hiv.pdf |title=National HIV & Syphilis Antenatal Sero-Prevalence Survey in SA 2005 |website=Doh.gov.za |format=PDF |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110702071149/http://doh.gov.za/docs/reports/2005/hiv.pdf |archivedate=2 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and 2007,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doh.gov.za/docs/reports/2007/antenatal/antenatal_report.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=26 July 2011|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=26 August 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726195226/http://www.doh.gov.za/docs/reports/2007/antenatal/antenatal_report.pdf|archivedate=26 July 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> the percentage of pregnant women with HIV per year was as follows:
{| class="wikitable" |- |'''Year:''' |1990 |1991 |1992 |1993 |1994 |1995 |1996 |1997 |1998 |1999 |2000 |2001 |2002 |2003 |2004 |2005 |2006 |2007 |2008 |2009 |2010 |2011<ref>The 2011 National Antenatal Sentinel HIV & syphilus prevalence survey in South Africa, National Department of Health of South Africa http://www.doh.gov.za</ref> |- |'''Percentage:''' |0.7 |1.7 |2.2 |4.0 |7.6 |10.4 |14.2 |17.0 |22.8 |22.4 |24.5 |24.8 |26.5 |27.9 |29.5 |30.2 |29.1 |28.0 |29.3 |29.4 |30.2 |29.5 |}
According to a 2006 study by the South African Department of Health, 13.3% of 9,950 Africans that were included in the poll had HIV. Out of 1,173 whites, 0.6% had HIV.<ref name=TheSouthAfricanDepartmentofHealthStudy>{{cite web|url=http://www.avert.org/safricastats.htm |title=The South African Department of Health Study, 2006 |publisher=Avert.org |accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref> These numbers are confirmed in a 2008 study by the [[Human Sciences Research Council (South Africa)|Human Sciences Research Council]] that found a 13.6% infection rate among Africans, 1.7% among Coloreds, 0.3% among Indians, and 0.3% among Whites.{{Dubious|reason=This is presented as a list of mutually distinct groups but is not one.|date=December 2013}}<ref>{{cite book|title=South African National HIV Prevalence, Incidence, Behaviour and Communication Survey, 2008 |publisher=[[Human Sciences Research Council (South Africa)|Human Sciences Research Council]]|date=2009|page=79|isbn=978-0-7969-2292-2|url=http://www.hsrc.ac.za/Document-3238.phtml|accessdate=2 December 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100522082857/http://www.hsrc.ac.za/Document-3238.phtml|archivedate=22 May 2010}}</ref>
In 2007, it was estimated that between 4.9 and 6.6 million of South Africa's 48 million people of all ages were infected with HIV, which is the virus that causes AIDS.<ref name="Epidemiological Fact Sheet">{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/globalatlas/predefinedReports/EFS2008/full/EFS2008_ZA.pdf |title=Epidemiological Fact Sheet on HIV and AIDS, 2008 (page 4 and 5) |format=PDF |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090325165708/http://www.who.int/globalatlas/predefinedReports/EFS2008/full/EFS2008_ZA.pdf |archivedate=25 March 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== Aids denialism under Thabo Mbeki == : ''See also [[HIV/AIDS denialism in South Africa]].''
=== 2000 === On 9 July 2000, then President [[Thabo Mbeki]] opened the [[International AIDS Society|International AIDS Conference]] in Durban with a speech not about HIV or AIDS but about extreme poverty in Africa. In the speech, he confirmed his belief that immune deficiency is a big problem in Africa but that one can't possibly attribute all immune deficiency-related diseases to a single virus.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.info.gov.za/speeches/2000/000714451p1001.htm |title=MBEKI: 13TH INTERNATIONAL AIDS CONFERENCE |publisher=Info.gov.za |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604103303/http://www.info.gov.za/speeches/2000/000714451p1001.htm |archivedate=4 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/826742.stm |title=Controversy dogs Aids forum |publisher=BBC News |date=10 July 2000 |accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
On 4 September 2000, Thabo Mbeki acknowledged during an interview with Time Magazine (South African edition) that HIV can cause AIDS but confirmed his opinion that HIV should not be regarded as the sole cause of immune deficiency. He said:
: ''...the notion that immune deficiency is only acquired from a single virus cannot be sustained. Once you say immune deficiency is acquired from that virus, your response will be anti-retroviral drugs. But if you accept that there can be a variety of reasons ... then you can have a more comprehensive treatment response.''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tac.org.za/newsletter/2000/ns000908.txt |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-06-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201215432/http://www.tac.org.za/newsletter/2000/ns000908.txt |archivedate=1 December 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Vos |first=Pierre De |url=http://constitutionallyspeaking.co.za/?p=1079 |title=Thabo Mbeki’s strange relationship with the truth continues – Constitutionally Speaking |publisher=Constitutionallyspeaking.co.za |date=28 May 2009 |accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
On 20 September 2000, then President Thabo Mbeki responded to a question in [[Parliament of South Africa|Parliament]] about his views. He said:
: ''All HIV/AIDS programmes of this government are based on the thesis that HIV causes AIDS. [But...] can a virus cause a syndrome? ... It can't, because a syndrome is a group of diseases resulting from acquired immune deficiency. Indeed, HIV contributes [to the collapse of the immune system], but other things contribute as well.''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aegis.com/news/woza/2000/IC000906.html |title=How can a virus cause a syndrome? asks Mbeki |publisher=Aegis.com |date=21 September 2000 |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526083439/http://www.aegis.com/news/woza/2000/IC000906.html |archivedate=26 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
=== 2001 === In 2001 the government appointed a panel of scientists, including a number of [[AIDS denialist]]s, to report back on the issue. The report suggested alternative treatments for HIV/AIDS, but the South African government responded that unless alternative scientific proof is obtained, it will continue to base its policy on the idea that the cause of AIDS is HIV.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/1260941.stm |title=South African split over Aids |publisher=BBC News |date=4 April 2001 |accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
===2003=== Despite international drug companies offering free or cheap anti-retroviral drugs, the Health Ministry remained hesitant about providing treatment for people living with HIV. Only in November 2003 did the government approve a plan to make anti-retroviral treatment publicly available. Prior to 2003, South Africans with HIV who used the public sector health system could get treatment for opportunistic infections but could not get anti-retrovirals.<ref name=TheSouthAfricanDepartmentofHealthStudy/>
=== 2006 === The effort to improve treatment of HIV/AIDS was damaged by the attitude of many figures in the government, including [[Thabo Mbeki|President Mbeki]]. The then health minister, [[Manto Tshabalala-Msimang]], advocated a diet of garlic, olive oil and lemon to cure the disease.<ref name=drbeetroot>{{cite news |first = Fran |last = Blandy |title = 'Dr Beetroot' hits back at media over Aids exhibition |publisher = Mail & Guardian Online |url = http://www.mg.co.za/articlepage.aspx?area=/breaking_news/breaking_news__national/&articleid=280903 |date = 16 August 2006 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070104191247/http://www.mg.co.za/articlepage.aspx?area=%2Fbreaking_news%2Fbreaking_news__national%2F&articleid=280903 |archivedate = 4 January 2007 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Although many scientists and political figures called for her removal, she was not removed from office until Mbeki himself was removed from office.<ref>[http://news.scotsman.com/topics.cfm?tid=460&id=1344522006] {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> These policies led to the deaths of over 300,000 South Africans.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lewandowsky, Mann, Bauld, Hastings, Loftus|title=The Subterranean War on Science|url=http://www.psychologicalscience.org/index.php/publications/observer/2013/november-2013/the-subterranean-war-on-science.html|work=Observer|publisher=[[Association for Psychological Science]]|accessdate=4 November 2013}}</ref>
=== 2007 === In August 2007, President Mbeki and Health Minister Tshabalala-Msimang dismissed Deputy Health Minister [[Nozizwe Madlala-Routledge]]. Madlala-Routledge has been widely credited by medical professionals and AIDS activists.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2007/08/12/ap4011089.html] {{dead link|date=August 2017}}</ref> Although she was officially dismissed for corruption, it was widely held that she was dismissed for her more mainstream beliefs about AIDS and its relation with HIV.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=125&art_id=nw20070808223254301C831843 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-08-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060615021453/http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1 |archivedate=15 June 2006 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== Role of the media in South Africa's epidemic == The South African press took a strong advocacy position during the [[denialism]] era under Thabo Mbeki.<ref name=mmalan>{{cite news |first=Mia |last=Malan |title=Shaping the conflict: factors influencing the representation of conflict around HIV/AIDS policy in the South African press |publisher=Mobilizing Media |year=2006 }}</ref><ref name=afinlay>{{cite news |first=A |last=Finlay |title= Exposing AIDS:Media’s impact in South Africa |publisher=Communicare 23(2) |date=December 2004 }}</ref> There are numerous examples of journalists taking the government to task for policy positions and public statements that were seen as irresponsible.<ref name=mmalan />{{rp|44}} Some of these examples include: attacks on Health Minister Manto Tshabalala-Msimang’s “garlic and potato” approach to treatment,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zapiro.com/cartoon/123054-040215st |title=Zapiro cartoon |publisher=Zapiro.com |date=15 February 2004 |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718151203/http://www.zapiro.com/cartoon/123054-040215st |archivedate=18 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> outrage at Mbeki’s statement that he never knew anyone who had died of AIDS,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mg.co.za/printformat/single/2003-09-29-we-dont-need-red-herrings |title=We don't need red hrrings |publisher=Mg.co.za |date=29 September 2003 |accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref> and coverage of the humiliating 2006 International AIDS Conference.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/2006-08-21-manto-defends-aids-policies |title=Manto defends AIDS policies |publisher=Mg.co.za |date=21 August 2006 |accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
It could be claimed that the news media have taken a less aggressive stance since the end of Mbeki’s presidency and the death of Tshabalala Msimang. The emergence of Jacob Zuma as party and state leader heralded what the press saw as a new era of AIDS treatment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unaids.org/en/resources/presscentre/featurestories/2009/november/20091101southafrica/ |title=President heralds new era |publisher=Unaids.org |accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref> However, this also means that HIV is afforded less news coverage. A recent study by the HIV/AIDS and the Media Project has shown that the quantity of HIV-related news coverage has declined dramatically from 2002/3 (what could be considered the pinnacle of government denialism) to the more recent “conflict resolution” phase under Zuma. Perhaps HIV has fallen into the traditional categories of being impersonal, undramatic, "old" news.<ref name="afinlay" /> The number of health journalists has also declined considerably.<ref name=cduncan>{{cite news |first=C |last=Duncan |title= HIV in the print media: A comparative and retrospective print media monitoring analysis |year=2009 }}</ref>
== See also == * [[HIV/AIDS in South African townships]] * [[Sexual violence in South Africa]] * [[46664 (concerts)]]
'''General:''' * [[HIV/AIDS in Lesotho]] * [[Health care in South Africa]] * [[HIV/AIDS in Africa]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Pieter Fourie "The Political Management of HIV and AIDS in South Africa: One burden too many?" Palgrave Macmillan, 2006, {{ISBN|0-230-00667-1}} * Fassin, Didier "When Bodies Remember: Experiences and Politics of AIDS in South Africa" University of California Press, 2007, {{ISBN|978-0-520-25027-7}} *{{cite book|editor-last1=Harber|editor-first1=A.|editor-last2=Palitza|editor-first2=K.|editor-last3=Ridgard|editor-first3=N.|editor-last4=Struthers|title=What is Left Unsaid: Reporting the South African HIV Epidemic|date=2010|publisher=Jacana Media|location=Auckland Park, South Africa|isbn=9781920196257|oclc=1017457773}}
==External links== {{Commons category|AIDS in South Africa}} *[http://www.aidsportal.org/overlay_details.aspx?nex=22 AIDSPortal South Africa page – latest research, guidelines and case studies] *[https://www.pbs.org/newshour/video/share.html?s=news01p824 NewsHour: HIV/AIDS and TB in South Africa] *[http://www.journaids.org JournAIDS: A resource on HIV for South African media practitioners] *[https://southafrica-info.com/people/hiv-aids-south-africa/ HIV and Aids in South Africa – South Africa Gateway]

revision.text:
[[File:Kabul Military Hospital - panoramio.jpg|thumb|One of the main hospitals in [[Kabul]], [[Afghanistan]]]] '''Health in Afghanistan''' is unsatisfactory but slowly improving. The [[Ministry of Public Health (Afghanistan)|Ministry of Public Health]] oversees all matters concerning the health of [[Demographics of Afghanistan|Afghanistan's population]]. According to the [[Human Development Index]], [[Afghanistan]] is the [[List of countries by Human Development Index|15th least developed country in the world]]. Its average [[List of countries by life expectancy|life expectancy]] at birth is reported at around 60 years.<ref name="WHO">{{cite web|url=http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/136852/1/ccsbrief_afg_en.pdf |title=Afghanistan |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] (WHO) |accessdate=2017-05-20}}</ref><ref name="UNESCO"/> The country's [[maternal mortality]] rate is 396 deaths/100,000 live births and its [[infant mortality]] rate is 66<ref name="UNESCO"/> to 112.8 deaths in every 1,000 live births.<ref name="Factbook"/>
There are over 100 government-run and private or internationally-administered [[List of hospitals in Afghanistan|hospitals in Afghanistan]]. The most advanced medical treatments are available in [[Kabul]]. The [[French Medical Institute for Children]] and [[Indira Gandhi Children's Hospital]] in Kabul are the leading [[children's hospital]]s in the country. The Kabul Military Hospital and the [[Jamhuriat Hospital]] are two of the popular hospitals in the country. In spite of all this, many Afghans still travel to [[Medical tourism in Pakistan|Pakistan]] and [[Medical tourism in India|India]] for advanced treatment.
==History== The decades of war have destroyed Afghanistan's already-poor health care system. Most medical professionals left the country by 1992, and all medical training programs ceased. In 2003, there were 11 [[physicians]] and 18 [[nurses]] per 100,000 population, and the per capita health expenditure was $28 [[US dollar]]s. The nation had one medical facility for every 27,000 people in 2004, and some centers were responsible for as many as 300,000 people. An estimated one-quarter of the population had no access to health care. The international organizations provided a large share of medical care. The drought of 1999–2002 exacerbated these conditions.
[[File:1960s Afghanistan - Infant ward in a Kabul hospital.jpg|thumb|200px|Infant ward at a Kabul hospital, 1960s]] It was reported in 2006 that an estimated 800,000 Afghans are [[disabled]].<ref name=cp>[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Afghanistan.pdf Afghanistan country profile]. [[Library of Congress]] [[Federal Research Division]] (May 2006). ''This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the [[public domain]].''</ref> [[infant mortality|Infant]], [[child mortality|child]], and [[maternal mortality]] rates in Afghanistan reached the highest in the world, by some estimates as high as 275 per 1,000.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} In rural areas, one in six children die before reaching age five.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} This is because of poor [[sanitation]] and insufficient [[potable water]] supply, [[infectious disease|infectious]] and [[parasitic disease]]s such as [[malaria]] and [[diarrhea]] are very common. [[Malnutrition]] and poor nutrition also are pervasive. [[File:Opening ceremony of the Kandahar Nursing and Midwifery Institute.jpg|thumb|Opening ceremony at a public health clinic in [[Kandahar Province|Kandahar province]] of Afghanistan (May 2012).]] User fees have been a major deterrent to accessing health care. Various interventions have been devised to improve uptake of health care services, including the distribution of waiver cards to very poor and female-headed households<ref>{{cite journal|last=Steinhardt|first=Laura|author2=David Peters|title=Targeting accuracy and impact of a community-identified waiver card scheme for primary care user fees in Afghanistan|journal=International Journal for Equity in Health|year=2010|volume=9|issue=28|doi=10.1186/1475-9276-9-28|url=http://www.futurehealthsystems.org/publications/targeting-accuracy-and-impact-of-a-community-identified-waiv.html|accessdate=18 May 2012}}</ref> and the introduction of community-based health insurance.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rao|first=K|title=An Experiment with Community Health Funds in Afghanistan|journal=Health Policy and Planning|date=27 May 2009|url=http://www.futurehealthsystems.org/publications/an-experiment-with-community-health-funds-in-afghanistan.html|accessdate=26 May 2012|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
Following the national user fee ban in 2008, a pilot study conducted by the Future Health Systems consortium found a 400% increase in utilization of services that had previously charged fees for services and medicine.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Steinhardt|first=Laura|author2=Iqbal Aman |author3=Iqbalshah Pakzad |author4=Binay Kumar |author5=Lakhwinder Singh |author6=David Peters |title=Removing user fees for basic health services: a pilot study and national roll-out in Afghanistan|journal=Health Policy and Planning|year=2011|volume=26|issue=Suppl 2|pages=ii92-ii103|doi=10.1093/heapol/czr069|url=http://www.futurehealthsystems.org/publications/removing-user-fees-for-basic-health-services-a-pilot-study-a.html|accessdate=18 May 2012|pmc=3247786}}</ref> The government's strategy to collaborate with non-governmental organisations<ref>{{cite journal|last=Arur|first=A|title=Contracting for Health and Curative Care Use in Afghanistan Between 2004 and 2005|journal=Health Policy and Planning|date=22 October 2009|url=http://www.futurehealthsystems.org/publications/contracting-for-health-and-curative-care-use-in-afghanistan.html|accessdate=26 May 2012|display-authors=etal}}</ref> has led to higher primary health outcomes among the poor,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hansen|first=Peter|title=Determinants of Primary Care Service Quality in Afghanistan|journal=Int J Qual Health Care|year=2008|volume=20|issue=6|pages=375–383|url=http://www.futurehealthsystems.org/publications/determinants-of-primary-care-service-quality-in-afghanistan.html|accessdate=26 May 2012|doi=10.1093/intqhc/mzn039|display-authors=etal}}</ref> with relatively high levels of perceived health care quality reported by clients in a recent study of primary care services.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hansen|first=Peter|title=Client Perceptions of the Quality of Primary Care Services in Afghanistan|journal=Int J Qual Health Care|year=2008|volume=20|issue=6|pages=384–391|url=http://www.futurehealthsystems.org/publications/client-perceptions-of-the-quality-of-primary-care-services-i.html|accessdate=26 May 2012|doi=10.1093/intqhc/mzn040|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
The physical and psychological effects of war have substantially increased the need for medical care. In the last decade a number of new [[List of hospitals in Afghanistan|hospitals]] were established, with the most advanced treatments being available in Kabul. The [[French Medical Institute for Children]] and [[Indira Gandhi Childrens Hospital]] in Kabul are the leading [[children's hospital]]s in the country. Some of the other main hospitals in Kabul include the 350-bed [[Jamhuriat Hospital]], the [[Sardar Mohammad Daud Khan]] Hospital,<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/22/world/asia/22afghanistan.html | work=The New York Times | first1=Ray | last1=Rivera | first2=Sharifullah | last2=Sahak | title=Blast Hits Military Hospital in Afghan Capital | date=21 May 2011}}</ref> and the [[Jinnah Hospital (Kabul)|Jinnah Hospital]], which is under construction. There are also a number of [[Afghan Armed Forces|military]]-controlled hospitals in different regions of the country. A new 350-bed hospital is under construction in the southern Afghan city of Kandahar.<ref>https://www.pajhwok.com/en/node/486178</ref>
==Health status== 2011 surveys show that 57 percent of Afghans say they have good or very good access to clinics or hospitals,<ref name="csm"/> and Afghans themselves pay approximately 75% of [[health care costs]] directly.<ref>{{cite news|agency=NPR|author=Renee Montagne|date=2011-12-21|accessdate=2012-01-16|title=USAID Helps To Improve Medical Care In Afghanistan|url=https://www.npr.org/2011/12/22/144111949/usaid-improves-medical-care-in-afghanistan}}</ref>
===Tuberculosis=== Tuberculosis is [[endemic (epidemiology)|endemic]] in Afghanistan, with over 76,000 cases reported per year. The United States Agency for International Development is engaged in promulgating [[DOTS]] ([[directly observed therapy, short course]]) treatments, as well as TB awareness and prevention.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usaid.gov/stories/afghanistan/ss_af_tb.html|title=Bringing Hope to Tuberculosis Patients|work=|publisher=United States Agency for International Development (USAID)|accessdate=2010-10-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528072441/http://www.usaid.gov/stories/afghanistan/ss_af_tb.html|archivedate=2010-05-28|df=}}</ref>
[[BRAC (NGO)|BRAC]] is a development organisation that focuses on the alleviation of poverty through the empowerment of the poor to improve their lives. BRAC Afghanistan is involved in assisting [[Afghan Ministry of Public Health]] in the implementation of the Basic Package of Health Services (BPHS) in Kabul, Badghis, Balkh and Nimroz. This implementation is mainly funded by the World Bank and the USAID-REACH (United States Agency for International Development - Rural Expansion of Afghanistan Community-based Healthcare).
Tuberculosis is a serious public health problem in Afghanistan. In 2007, 8,200 people in the country died from tuberculosis and, in the WHO's Global Tuberculosis Control Report 2009, an annual estimated figure of 46,000 new cases of tuberculosis were in Afghanistan. As such, Afghanistan is ranked 22nd in amongst highly affected Tuberculosis countries.<ref>{{cite web |author=Chris Thomas, Global Health/Health Infectious Diseases and Nutrition |url=http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/id/tuberculosis/countries/asia/afghanistan_profile.html |title=USAID Health: Infectious Diseases, Tuberculosis, Countries, Afghanistan |publisher=USAID |date=2009-09-22 |accessdate=2011-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110805163803/http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/id/tuberculosis/countries/asia/afghanistan_profile.html |archivedate=2011-08-05 |df= }}</ref>
To help control tuberculosis, BRAC Afghanistan started the community-based [[TB DOTS]] under the ''Fund for Innovative DOTS Expansion through Local Initiatives to Stop TB (FIDELIS)'' project in 2006. In the first phase of this programme, diagnostic facilities for tuberculosis were expanded through the setting up of 50 TB microscopy centres. This phase lasted from January 2006 and up to March 2007. Over the next two years, facilities were further expanded and 92 more Tuberculosis Microscopy Centres were set up under the FIDELIS programme.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tbalert.org/worldwide/DOTS.php |title=DOTS |publisher=Tbalert.org |accessdate=2011-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728083404/http://www.tbalert.org/worldwide/DOTS.php |archivedate=2011-07-28 |df= }}</ref>
The Tuberculosis Control Assistance Programme (TB CAP) is another project taken up between BRAC Afghanistan, [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) and Management Sciences for Health (MSH) in a bid to fight TB in Afghanistan. In this project, BRAC Afghanistan supports the BPHS (Basic Package of Health Services) project by replicating the CB-DOTS model into health systems of four provinces: Baghlan, Jawzjan, Badakshan and Herat. BRAC Afghanistan was selected as Principal Recipient (PR) for malaria and TB components of the Global Fund 8.<ref>{{cite web |author=SWiSH v2.0 |url=http://www.bracafg.org/cbh1.php |title=BRAC Afghanistan (Bangladesh)- Community Based Health Program |publisher=Bracafg.org |accessdate=2011-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110830022328/http://www.bracafg.org/cbh1.php |archivedate=2011-08-30 |df= }}</ref>
In 2009, 2,143,354 patients received treatment under the health programs mentioned. As of August 2010, BRAC Afghanistan had covered 388 districts and 25 million of the total population are under the BRAC Afghanistan Health Program. Health facilities also include six District Hospitals, 26 Comprehensive Health Centres, 53 Basic Health Centres, 18 Sub Health Centres as well as 533 Mobile Clinics every month.<ref>http://www.bracafg.org/report/At%20A%20Glance%20of%20BRAC%20Afghanistan%20as%20of%20August2010.pdf</ref>
===HIV=== The prevalence of HIV in Afghanistan is 0.04%.<ref name="Factbook"/> According to Afghanistan's National Aids Control Program (NACP), 504 cases of HIV/AIDS were documented in late 2008.<ref>[http://www.unicef.org/infobycountry/afghanistan_46717.html Children at risk of contracting HIV/AIDS in Afghanistan]. December 1, 2008.</ref> By the end of 2012, the numbers reached 1,327. Afghanistan's healthy ministry stated that most of the HIV patients were among [[Intravenous therapy|intravenous]] [[drug user]]s and that 70% of them were men, 25% women, and the remaining 5% children. They belonged to Kabul, Kandahar and Herat, the provinces from where people make the most trips to neighboring or other foreign countries.<ref name="over-1300-hiv-cases-registered-afghanistan">{{cite news |url=http://www.pajhwok.com/en/2012/12/01/over-1300-hiv-cases-registered-afghanistan |title=Over 1,300 HIV cases registered in Afghanistan |publisher=Pajhwok Afghan News |date=December 1, 2012 |accessdate=2012-12-02}}</ref> Regarding Kandahar, 22 cases were reported in 2012. "AIDS Prevention department head Dr Hamayoun Rehman said 1,320 blood samples were examined and 21 were positive. Among the 21 patients, 18 were males and three were females who contracted the deadly virus from their husbands. He said four people had reached a critical stage while three had died. The main source of the disease was the use of [[syringe]]s used by drug addicts."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.pajhwok.com/en/2012/12/02/aids-patients-have-doubled-kandahar-official |title=AIDS patients have doubled in Kandahar: Official |publisher=Pajhwok Afghan News |date=December 2, 2012 |accessdate=2012-12-03}}</ref> There are approximately 23,000 addicts in the country who inject drugs into their bodies using syringes. As of 2015, as much as 6,900 people are living in Afghanistan with HIV and about 300 have died in from the disease.<ref name="Factbook"/>
'''Poliomyelitis'''
The Afghan Ministry of Public Health along with [[World Health Organization]] and [[UNICEF]] are engaged in a campaign to eliminate polio in the country. Wild poliovirus is present in Afghanistan, though in limited areas. Reported cases were on the decline, from 63 in 1999 to 17 in 2007, until increased violence in 2008 impeded vaccination efforts, causing cases to climb to 20 for the first nine months of 2009. Afghanistan, the remaining country where polio is endemic. Most of Afghanistan is polio-free. The country has not yet interrupted transmission of wild poliovirus. While most cases in 2014, 2015 and 2016 were due to poliovirus imported from neighbouring Pakistan, there is also ongoing transmission of virus within Afghanistan. In 2015 and from January/2016 to September/ 2016. Afghanistan had a major reduction in WPV cases. The majority of cases were reported from Nangarhar province in eastern Afghanistan, which borders Pakistan, and were genetically linked to cases in Pakistan. Afghanistan reported 20 cases in 16 districts in 2015, compared with 28 cases in 19 districts in 2014, and 8 cases in 2016, The most recent case had onset of paralysis on 8 August/2016, from Kabul.
'''Malnutrition'''
More than half of Afghan girls and boys suffer damage to their minds and bodies that cannot be undone because they are poorly nourished in the crucial first two years of life. High levels of Malnutrition in Children is rate of stunting 60.5%, One third of children (33.7%) underweight, Anaemia 50% in children 6–24 months, High iodine deficiency: 72%(school age) and also the high levels of Malnutrition in Women is Iron deficiency: 48.4%, non-pregnant and Iodine deficiency 75%.and high levels of chronic energy deficiency are 20.9% low BMI. Supporting the Implementation of Nutrition (and Health)-Specific Interventions through BPHS and EPHS. The [[Afghan Ministry of Public Health|Ministry of Public Health]], [[World Bank]] and WFP are working together for ensuring that mothers are healthy before they become pregnant and throughout pregnancy, promoting appropriate Infant and Young Child Feeding Practices, ensuring that children receive adequate health care to prevent growth faltering resulting from illness and early treatment of acute malnutrition and Promote appropriate hygiene practices.
===Leprosy=== Despite anti-leprosy initiatives by [[Leprosy Control]] (LEPCO) dating to 1984, [[leprosy]] is present in Afghanistan, with 231 cases reported in the 2001-2007 period. Just over three-quarters of the cases were the MB-type, with the rest PB-type. Leprosy has been reported in the central [[Hindu Kush]] mountain area of the country. Mainly in the provinces of [[Bamyan Province|Bamyan]], [[Ghazni Province|Ghazni]], [[Balkh Province|Balkh]].<ref>[http://www.ilep.org.uk/fileadmin/uploads/Country_Pages/Afghanistan/Afghanistan.pdf Leprosy Situation in Afghanistan in 2001-2006]. [[Afghan Ministry of Public Health|Ministry of Public Health]] (MoPH) National Leprosy Control Program. 7–9 July 2008.</ref>
===Typhoid fever=== Being the 15th least developed country in the world, Afghanistan faces difficulties in sanitation. In urban areas 40% of the population have unimproved access to sanitation facilities. Because of this many Afghanistan natives are forced to combat typhoid fever. Typhoid fever is one of Afghanistan's major infectious diseases in terms of food/waterborne diseases. This infectious disease occurs when fecal material comes into contact with food or water. Symptoms vary from case to case but often mild fever is present and if left untreated death may occur.<ref name="Factbook"/>
===Hepatitis A=== Sanitation issues place the Afghanistan population at risk of contracting hepatitis A through the consumption of food and water that has been contaminated by fecal material. Hepatitis A works by inhibiting the liver from functioning properly. Symptoms generally include jaundice, fatigue, loss of appetite, while some victims may experience diarrhea. Furthermore, symptoms will appear 2–6 weeks after an individual has come into contact with the hepatitis A virus.<ref name="Factbook"/> Efforts have been made to fight hepatitis through efforts by the Pashtun community. Tribal leader Davud Suleimankhel is credited with establishing an organization that teaches people about Hepatitis, Tuberculosis, and other diseases. In a speech to the Jalalabad Pashtun League, he said that "the red-blooded vigor of the Pashtuns and the iron soul of Afghanistan shall not falter in the face of disease".{{cn|date=April 2018|reason=Supporting cite required for direct quotations}} Various aid organizations have also started to work in Afghanistan to combat Hepatitis.
===Leishmaniasis=== [[Visceral leishmaniasis]] infections are often recognised by fever, swelling of the liver and spleen, and [[anemia]]. They are known by many local names, of which the most common is probably ''[[Kala azar]]''.<ref name=humber>[http://www.irinnews.org/film/4171/Kala-Azar Kala Azar]</ref><ref name=kala-azar>[http://www.bartleby.com/61/51/K0005100.html kala-azar] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090210143548/http://www.bartleby.com/61/51/K0005100.html |date=2009-02-10 }}. The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language</ref> A total of 21 cases of VL acquired in Afghanistan, all in the 1980s according to CDC reporting.<ref name=cdc-kala-azar>[https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5312a5.htm]. Two Cases of Visceral Leishmaniasis in U.S. Military Personnel</ref>
===Maternal and child health care=== {{Further information|Afghanistan Midwifery Project}} [[File:Recovery area of a hospital in Kabul.jpg|thumb|Mothers and infants receiving [[health care]] at a hospital in [[Kabul]].]]
Afghanistan made significant improvement in the last decade to its maternal and child health care. According to [[United States Agency for International Development]] (USAID), Afghanistan's [[mortality rate]] has decreased by about 25% since 2003. It was reported in 2006 that nearly 60% of the population lives within two hours walking distance of the nearest health facility.<ref name="USAID-Health">{{cite web|url=https://www.usaid.gov/afghanistan/health |title=Health |work=[[United States Agency for International Development]] (USAID) |publisher=www.usaid.gov |accessdate=October 20, 2010}}</ref>
The [[maternal mortality]] rate is currently 396 deaths/100,000 live births and its [[infant mortality]] rate is 66<ref name="UNESCO">{{cite web|url=http://uis.unesco.org/country/af |title=Afghanistan |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=2017-05-20}}</ref> to 112.8 deaths in every 1,000 live births.<ref name="Factbook">{{cite web |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/af.html |title=Afghanistan |work=The World Factbook |publisher=www.cia.gov |accessdate=2017-05-20}}</ref> The Ministry of Public Health wants to further improve these higher rates by making them normal.
The country has more than 3,000 [[midwifery|midwives]], with an additional 300 to 400 being trained each year.<ref name="csm">{{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/childbirth-maternal-health-improve-afghanistan-160657704.html |title=Childbirth and maternal health improve in Afghanistan |first=Tom A. |last=Peter |publisher=Christian Science Monitor |date=17 December 2011 |accessdate=12 January 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231002243/http://news.yahoo.com/childbirth-maternal-health-improve-afghanistan-160657704.html |archivedate=31 December 2013 }}</ref> According to Sima Ayubi, a maternity doctor in Kabul who advocates hospital births, explains: "Now pregnant women have more information about health. This mortality rate is still a problem. There's just a decrease. The problem is not completely eliminated or under control."<ref name="csm"/>
According to a 2012 report by [[Save the Children]], improved healthcare and the rise of females attending school have made Afghanistan climb up from its position as the worst place on earth to be a mother. "More mothers are surviving and fewer children are dying and this is something we need to be celebrating," said Rachel Maranto, Advocacy and Mobilisation senior Manager at Save the Children in Kabul.
==See also== *[[List of hospitals in Afghanistan]] *[[Ministry of Public Health (Afghanistan)]] *[[Environmental issues in Afghanistan]]

{{Asia topic|Health in}}
[[Category:Health in Afghanistan]]

{{Infobox university |image = JH Nursing.jpg |image_size = 330px |name = Johns Hopkins University School of Nursing |motto=''Vigilando'' ([[Latin]]) |mottoeng=Forever Watchful<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nursing.jhu.edu/alumni/symbols/ |title=Symbols | Johns Hopkins University School of Nursing |publisher=Nursing.jhu.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref> |established = 1889 |type = [[Private school|Private]] |dean = Patricia Davidson<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nursing.jhu.edu/about-us/welcome/dean.html |title=Dean's Message | School of Nursing at Johns Hopkins University |publisher=Nursing.jhu.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref> |city = [[Baltimore, Maryland|Baltimore]] |state = [[Maryland]] |country = [[United States|USA]] |students = 1075 (2014)<ref name="JHUSONinfo1">{{cite web|url=http://nursing.jhu.edu/about-us/welcome/facts.html|title=Facts and Figures}}</ref> |faculty = 230 (80 full-time, 150 part-time)<ref name="JHUSONinfo1"/> |campus = [[urban area|Urban]] |website= http://nursing.jhu.edu/ |logo= [[Image:Jhumedinst.JPG|255px|The JHMI Campus Logo]] }} The '''Johns Hopkins University School of Nursing''' ('''JHUSON''') is part of the [[Johns Hopkins University]] located in [[Baltimore, Maryland]], [[United States]]. Established in 1889, it is one of the nation’s oldest and [[Nursing school|schools for nursing education]], ranking 2nd in the nation.<ref name="rank">{{cite web|url = http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-nursing-schools/nur-rankings?int=a23009|title = U.S. News & World Report: Best Nursing Graduate Schools Rankings|publisher = U.S. News & World Report|year = 2015|accessdate = 2015-12-01}}</ref> It is also among the top recipients of [[nursing research]] funding from the [[National Institutes of Health]].<ref name="JHUSONinfo1"/> The school's mission is to provide leadership to improve [[health care]] and advance the [[nursing]] profession through education, research, practice, and service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nursing.jhu.edu/about-us/welcome/mission.html |title=Mission & Goals | Johns Hopkins University School of Nursing |publisher=Nursing.jhu.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref>
==Origins== The founder [[Johns Hopkins]]' desire for a training school for female nurses was formally stated in a posthumous 1873 instruction letter to the board of trustees of the Johns Hopkins institutions. The School of Nursing in conjunction with the [[Johns Hopkins Hospital]] was eventually founded in 1889 after in depth consultation with [[Florence Nightingale]] on its planning, organization, structure and curriculum.<ref>[http://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/about/history/history8.html History of the School of Nursing]</ref>
==Location== The Johns Hopkins University School of Nursing is located on the [[Johns Hopkins University]] East Baltimore campus along with the [[Bloomberg School of Public Health]], [[Johns Hopkins School of Medicine|School of Medicine]], and the [[Johns Hopkins Hospital]].
==Programs== The School of Nursing offers a variety of programs from pre-licensure programs to Master's, DNP and PhD programs, online options, post-degree opportunities, and nursing prerequisites.<ref>{{cite web|title=Academic Programs at Johns Hopkins University School of Nursing|url=http://nursing.jhu.edu/academics/programs/index.html|accessdate=15 October 2012}}</ref>
=== Pre-licensure program options ===
* Master's Entry into Nursing (21 months)
=== Master of Science in Nursing program options === * [[Adult-gerontology nurse practitioner|Adult-Geriatric Primary Care Nurse Practitioner]] * [[Adult-gerontology nurse practitioner|Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner]] * [[Family nurse practitioner|Family Primary Care Nurse Practitioner]] * [[Pediatric nurse practitioner|Pediatric Primary Care Nurse Practitioner]] * [[Clinical nurse specialist|Clinical Nurse Specialist]] (online option available) * Health Systems Management (online option available) * Health Systems Management/Clinical Nurse Specialist Dual Track * [[Master of Science in Nursing]]/[[Master of Business Administration]] (MSN/MBA) * [[Public health nursing|Public Health Nursing]] * [[Nurse midwife|Public Health Nursing, Nurse-Midwifery Track]] * [[Master of Science in Nursing]]/[[Master of Public Health]] (MSN/MPH) * [[Nurse practitioner|Nurse Practitioner]] with Public Health Nursing Focus (MSN-NP/MPH)
=== Doctor of Nursing Practice ===
=== Doctor of Philosophy in Nursing === The school has four research centers (Center for Innovative Care in Aging, Center for Nursing Research and Sponsored Projects, Center for Collaborative Intervention Research and the Center on Health Disparities Research)<ref>[http://www.son.jhmi.edu/research/overview.aspx ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081222023527/http://www.son.jhmi.edu/research/overview.aspx |date=December 22, 2008 }}</ref> and also offers Interdisciplinary Fellowship research on [[violence]], [[pain]], and [[health]] disparities in underserved populations, as well as research focused on [[cardiovascular]] [[Preventive medicine|health prevention]] and [[Absolute risk reduction|risk reduction]], [[End-of-life (medical treatment)|care at end of life]], community-based [[health promotion]], health disparities, interpersonal violence, maternal-[[child health]], [[psychoneuroimmunology]], and [[symptom]] management areas.<ref name="JHUSONinfo1"/> The school is also home to the country’s first and only [[Peace Corps]] Fellows Program in nursing.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-12082817_ITM | work=AScribe Medicine News Service | title=Peace Corps Fellows Nursing Program Nearly Doubles | date=2005-12-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Media-Newswire.com - Press Release Distribution |url=http://media-newswire.com/release_1071571.html |title=Press Release Distribution - PR Agency |publisher=Media-Newswire.com |date=2008-08-22 |accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Peace Corps |url=http://www.peacecorps.gov/index.cfm?shell=learn.whyvol.eduben.school_detail&coll_prog_id=14&program=F |title=Johns Hopkins University – School of Nursing | Coverdell Fellows | Peace Corps |publisher=Peacecorps.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-09-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308161557/http://www.peacecorps.gov/index.cfm?shell=learn.whyvol.eduben.school_detail&coll_prog_id=14&program=F |archivedate=2012-03-08 |df= }}</ref> The school offers a special program for Arts and Science College students to transfer after two years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jhu.edu/design/oliver/1476onlinehandbook/academic_manual/opportunities.html#nursing|title=Nursing|publisher=Johns Hopkins University|accessdate=2010-11-27}}</ref>
==Reputation and Ranking==
The Johns Hopkins School of Nursing ranks #1 nationally among graduate schools of nursing and #3 for online programs, according to ''U.S. News & World Report,'' and was named the [http://www.bestmasterofscienceinnursing.com/20-innovative-degree-programs/ Most Innovative Nursing Graduate Program in the U.S.] by Best Master of Science in Nursing Degrees. The school ranks #1 among nursing schools for Federal Research Grants and National Institutes of Health (NIH) funding. Nearly 95 percent of graduates pass the NCLEX on their first try. Among the faculty, more than 40 percent are ranked as Fellows of the American Academy of Nursing. The school has clinics across Baltimore that reach out to abused women, struggling mothers and other underrepresented communities, giving over 12,000 volunteer hours annually and conducting 40 different community-based service programs. The School of Nursing is associated with nursing practice at Johns Hopkins Hospital, ranked #1 in the United States an unprecedented 22 times by ''U.S. News & World Report''.
==Distinguished Alumni in Nursing History== *[[Mary Adelaide Nutting]] (World's first professor of nursing) *[[Isabel Hampton Robb]] (Founder of modern American [[nursing theory]] and one of the most important leaders in the [[history of nursing]], first Dean of the School) *[[Elizabeth Lawrie Smellie]] (First woman Colonel of the Canadian army and Matron-in-chief of the [[Canadian Army Medical Corps]]) *[[Ernestine Wiedenbach]] (Major nursing theorist in [[Maternal-child nursing|maternity]] and clinical nursing) *[[Vashti Bartlett]], Red Cross nurse during World War I, and in Vladivostok, Manchuria, and Haiti
==Publications== *[http://magazine.nursing.jhu.edu Johns Hopkins Nursing Magazine] *[http://dailyson.com The Daily SON]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Portal|Nursing}} *[http://nursing.jhu.edu Official Website] *[http://blogs.nursing.jhu.edu Johns Hopkins Nursing Blogs]
==Further reading== * James, Janet Wilson. "Isabel Hampton and the Professionalization of Nursing in the 1890s," in Morris J. Vogel and Charles E. Rosenberg, eds. ''Therapeutic Revolution: Essays in the Social History of American Medicine'' (1979) pp 201–244 * Kaufman M et al. ''Dictionary of American medical biography''. Greenwood Press, Westport CN, vol 2. Page 640. * Ramos, Mary Carol. "The Johns Hopkins Training School For Nurses: A Tale Of Vision, Labor, And Futility," ''Nursing History Review'' (1997), Vol. 5, pp 23–48.
{{JHU}} {{Johns Hopkins Health System}}
